messages.message:
i’m not sure where to start this discussion, but here goes! :sweat_smile:

as mentioned during Q&A for the tech talk on Monday, it’s inconvenient for product engineers to use a fresh MySQL db in their dev environment
• setting up AI Hub for a fresh db is difficult (example (https://instabase.slack.com/archives/C05L87V014J/p1733778752131259))
    ◦ this is currently not captured in the new eng onboarding doc (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yQOCxOISV_ukUxXdPJDoN-rERtOhdVRe7zv1swF1igw/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.ozg2l97f461a) btw
• reproducing bugs will take a while if we have to reproduce every bug from scratch on our dev environment
• the problem is even worse for indexes for AI Hub Search
ideally, product engineers can use a deployed environment’s db / indexes in their dev environment
• we can already use dogfood.instabase.com (http://dogfood.instabase.com)’s db, which is nice since it already has the necessary users / models / etc for running AI Hub
• however, it’d even more ideal if we could use the db from an actual AI Hub environment (ex: crafting-aihub.test.instabase.com (http://crafting-aihub.test.instabase.com))
    ◦ this way, if a product engineer is able to reproduce a bug on crafting-aihub, they don’t need to re-create the bug scenario in their dev environment -> they can directly fix the bug and test the fix in their dev environment since they’re using the same db as crafting-aihub
i’ve asked multiple people about this over the years, but it seems that our SaaS sandbox dbs are in a VPC that prevents external network access - however, i’m hoping we can make an exception for 1 AI Hub sandbox?

this would make eng onboarding even simpler for product engineers and would speed up debugging a lot :pray:

I think the problem with this though is that many product eng also make changes to the db schema for various features they are building, and having in-development changes hit a shared database is also a bad idea. 

I think a nicer option is if there’s a way to clone the aihub dogfood database (periodically) so that you have access to real data, but you also won’t risk taking down everyone’s environment with a bad database change.

If someone is making changes to the db schema, they should definitely use a local db for testing, not a shared db

Cloning the aihub-sandbox db would also be helpful! That would solve the first-time AI Hub setup issues and unblock most test cases
